snippet: The so-called rebates that stock exchanges pay Wall Street firms could give those firms an incentive to profit at the expense of investors, experts find.
abstract: Former regulators find so-called rebates that stock exchanges pay Wall Street firms to send them business could give those firms an incentive to profit at the expense of investors; study by Woodbine Associates, which uses industry data, says rebates could be costing mutual funds, pension funds and ordinary investors as much as $5 billion a year. (M)
lead_paragraph: The rules governing Wall Street generally force stockbrokers to seek out the best prices for clients who pay them to buy and sell shares. In recent years, though, brokers have had another enticement that can pull them in a different direction: payments from stock exchanges in return for sending them business.

headline.main: Study Says Broker Rebates Cost Investors Billions
